At the same time, overcrowded prisons too often fail to meet basic human rights standards. Under existing conditions, these sentences are inhumane. A president can use her clemency powers to right systemic injustice‚Äîand I plan to do just that.

Data show that people tend to age out of crime and are less likely to recidivate, but thousands of elderly people remain behind bars. Those serving sentences equivalent to life are disproportionately Black and Brown, many for nonviolent crimes or crimes committed as juveniles.

Today I'm announcing that, in a Warren administration, we will create a clemency board that will prioritize cases of older Americans incarcerated for unduly long sentences and establish a presumption of release, unless the board finds a danger to public safety.

The president has significant powers to grant clemency and pardons, and historically presidents have used that power broadly. But today‚Äôs hierarchical process at DOJ results in relatively few and conservative clemency recommendations.

The banking industry wants you to believe people who file for bankruptcy are reckless or irresponsible. The truth is that they're struggling with rising costs and flat wages. One crisis is enough to send them over the edge. They don‚Äôt need shaming. They need relief.
Finally, I'll close the loopholes that allow the wealthy and corporate creditors to abuse the bankruptcy system at the expense of everyone else.

Bankruptcy also doesn‚Äôt affect all people equally. Women and people of color are more likely to file for bankruptcy, which is partly a reflection of wealth and income disparities. I'll take additional steps to target specific problems to help eliminate these shameful disparities.
My plan also makes it easier for people to protect their homes and cars in bankruptcy so they can start from a better foundation as they try to rebuild their financial lives.

We have a student loan debt crisis in America in part because our bankruptcy system makes it nearly impossible to get rid of that debt, even when you have nothing left. While I'm fighting to cancel student loan debt, I'll also fight to make that debt dischargeable in bankruptcy.

Bankruptcy law places certain spending limitations on people while they‚Äôre in the process of bankruptcy. My plan pares back some of those burdensome limits‚Äîlike those that prevent families from paying rent‚Äîso families have a chance to recover after the bankruptcy process.

My plan starts by making it easier for people being crushed by debt to obtain relief through bankruptcy by streamlining the process, reducing the costs of filing, and giving people more flexibility in bankruptcy to find solutions that match their financial problems.

In 2005, the banking industry pushed through a bill to change our bankruptcy laws so they could squeeze everything they could out of families. The bill hit working families hard and resulted in 250,000 more foreclosures during the financial crisis. It's time for an overhaul.

I spent most of my career studying why American families go broke. What I discovered was that they weren't reckless or irresponsible‚Äîthey were being squeezed by an economy that forced them to take on more debt, and one bad break sent them tumbling over the edge.

This economy is pushing struggling families to the breaking point, and our bankruptcy laws make it harder for them to get back on their feet. That's not right. I've got a plan to overhaul our consumer bankruptcy rules. https://t.co/WNanN0p2fb

Giant companies are raking in profits while squeezing working families to the breaking point. It's time to put more power in the hands of workers. My plan ensures that the 27 million part-time workers in America are treated with respect and can build a future for their families.

And it's time to remove the perverse incentives that keep giant corporations from making their workers full-time. I'll extend leave and benefit protections to part-time workers, and require employers to offer additional hours to existing part-time workers before hiring new ones.

My plan will give workers who work at companies with more than 15 employees the rest they desperately need by guaranteeing workers 11 hours between shifts and compensating them with higher pay for hours voluntarily worked within that window.

Under my Fair Workweek Plan, employers with 15 or more employees will be required to give two weeks‚Äô advance notice of work schedules. And employees will be empowered to ask for schedules that work for them, without fear of retaliation.

These unpredictable schedules make it nearly impossible to work another job, go back to school, or schedule child care. And workers of color‚Äîespecially women of color‚Äîbear the brunt of these abusive scheduling practices.

Millions of workers face unpredictable schedules that can change dramatically day-to-day‚Äîeven by the hour‚Äîwith almost no advance warning. A third of workers involuntarily work part-time because they aren't assigned enough hours by giant corporations trying to keep costs down.

As corporations rake in larger profits, working families across the country are getting crushed by rising costs and wages that are barely budging. Adding to their challenges, many employers‚Äîespecially in the retail and service industries‚Äîare using algorithms to assign schedules.

Unpredictable work schedules are leaving too many part-time workers with no control over their time and not enough hours to make ends meet. My Fair Workweek Plan will put power in the hands of part-time workers and help them control their schedules. https://t.co/z15jWSK8OQ

It worked. Eventually, everyone got back to eating and talking‚Äîand Aunt Max was never in charge of bringing the turkey again.

So no matter what cooking disasters, miscommunications, or accidents happen this Thanksgiving, smile, readjust, and try not to take it too seriously!

An uproar followed as everyone loudly explained that ‚Äúbring the turkey‚Äù meant a cooked turkey. Aunt Max considered that, then laughed. She said we'd eat Thanksgiving dinner in layers‚Äîa Jell-O course, a potato course, a pie course‚Äîfinishing with a turkey course, in about 6 hours.

They burst through the front door, and Uncle Crowbar banged the heavy roaster on the kitchen countertop as people crowded around to see the turkey. With a flourish, Aunt Max lifted the lid, proclaiming, ‚ÄúBiggest Turkey Ever!‚Äù

Everyone jumped back. It was RAW.

My mother fretted and Aunt Alice fumed. The boys buzzed around trying to get a spoonful of this or a crust of that. Aunt Bee tried to keep everything in order. Still no Aunt Max. Then one of the boys spotted her coming up the walk with Uncle Crowbar (that name is another story).

Thanksgiving dinner was set for noon, and most of the family was there by mid-morning. The table was set. The sweet potato casseroles were out of the oven. The pies were on display. The Jell-O molds were out on special plates. Food was piled everywhere. But‚Äîno Aunt Max.

Aunt Max was funny and quick-talking. She never took anything too seriously, including time. And she wasn‚Äôt much of a cook, so the other sisters made sure that she was up to the task‚Äîpeppering her with questions, making sure she'd get a big enough turkey.

Thanksgiving was always a big gathering in our family. The holiday brought in family from Texas, Arkansas, and Kansas. That meant LOTS of planning over who would bring what, how much, and so on.

One year, Aunt Max, my mother‚Äôs oldest sister, volunteered to bring the turkey. https://t.co/7VS3mDxfSg

@AyannaPressley America was founded on principles of liberty and built on the backs of enslaved people.

@AyannaPressley And now more than ever, all of us have to embrace the lessons of Black history. The rich and powerful aren‚Äôt going to just give away their power. No, if we want power, we have to fight for it!

@AyannaPressley The rich and powerful want us to be afraid of each other, because they‚Äôre afraid of us. Afraid of the people. Afraid of seeing us stand together. Afraid that we will take up each other‚Äôs fights as our own. Afraid that they will lose their power.

@AyannaPressley Divide and conquer is an old political tactic‚Äîand it comes in all sorts of ugly flavors: Racist, sexist, homophobic, transphobic, xenophobic. It‚Äôs the phobic‚Äîthat‚Äôs the key part. It‚Äôs all about fear. Politics based in fear.

@AyannaPressley Today our government is working great for billionaires. Working great for giant corporations. Working great for those who cheerfully suck up as much wealth as they can, and never glance back at who gets left behind.

@AyannaPressley Donald Trump didn‚Äôt create this divide and conquer system. But he wouldn‚Äôt be in power without it. After eight years of progress under President Obama, Trump‚Äôs embrace of white supremacy, white nationalism, and corruption threaten to break our democracy beyond repair.
@AyannaPressley And when Black people won the fight to end school segregation and demanded federal funding for their children‚Äôs educations, poor white children got better educations, too.
@AyannaPressley When Black civil rights warriors won the fight for voting rights, voter turnout all across the South‚Äîfor Blacks and whites‚Äîskyrocketed.

@AyannaPressley So, I want to speak directly to the question on some white people‚Äôs minds when we talk about the need to address what our government has done in Black communities. The uncomfortable question of ‚Äúwhat will this mean for me‚Äù?
@AyannaPressley To this day racism still whispers the convenient lie to some white people that if your life has problems, you should blame ‚Äúthem‚Äù‚Äîpeople who don‚Äôt look like you.

@AyannaPressley Black history is American history. And American history teaches us that racism has for generations shaped every crucial aspect of our economy and political system. https://t.co/mUjJqwvwjf

@AyannaPressley Racist politicians doubled down. They divided Black people and white people in every moment of every day of every life, using force, violence, and intimidation to oppress Blacks and to ensure that Blacks and whites would never come together to stand up against those in power.
@AyannaPressley The law had promised equal civil and legal rights for all, and its loss was another body blow to our fragile, reconstructed democracy.

@AyannaPressley In 1883, two years after the successful washerwomen‚Äôs strike and as other groups were just beginning to exercise some political muscle, the Supreme Court struck down a civil rights law that had been passed in the wake of the Civil War.

@AyannaPressley But the gains were fleeting. As the idea that Black workers and white workers could make real structural change if they fought side by side began to spark to life, an evil force was once again mobilizing against it.
@AyannaPressley Then it happened. The employers, the city council, the powerful white citizens‚Äîthey all backed down. The women won!

@AyannaPressley And when the City Council threatened to intervene, the women sent a public letter to the mayor of Atlanta and said they would not back down. They went right to the heart of the matter: ‚ÄúWe mean business.‚Äù

@AyannaPressley Black women‚Äîthen and now‚Äîare no strangers to facing resistance when they fight for justice, and Black women‚Äîthen and now‚Äîdon‚Äôt give up easy. Even in the face of imminent violence, Black women refused to be defined by fear. So, the women of the Washing Society persisted.
@AyannaPressley The employers struck back. They warned that they would use their money and power to start their own modern industrial laundry service to replace the washerwomen permanently.
@AyannaPressley In the space of three weeks, 20 women on strike became 200 women. And 200 women on strike became 2,000 women. 2,000 became 3,000.

@AyannaPressley One day, they had enough. It was July 1881, when 20 of Atlanta‚Äôs Black washerwomen threw down their washboards, walked away from their barrels‚Äîand formed a union: The Washing Society.

@AyannaPressley By nightfall, everything was folded and stacked, ready to be dropped off the next morning when they picked up a new pile of dirty laundry. And so the cycle continued‚Äîall for less than a dollar a day.

@AyannaPressley Black women and girls found that pretty much the only work white employers allowed them to do was the work that they‚Äôd been forced to do when they had been enslaved‚Äîcaring for white families. Thousands of women scratched out a living as washerwomen. The work was heavy.
@AyannaPressley I want to tell a story. The year was 1881. After the tyranny of slavery, thousands of African Americans came to Atlanta hoping to build new lives, lives full of promise.

@AyannaPressley I‚Äôm here to make a commitment: When I am president of the United States, the lessons of Black history will not be lost. Those lessons, they will live in every part of my presidency‚Äîand I will ask you to hold me accountable for that promise every single day. https://t.co/kIhG74rLCU

Ten years to the day later, the Supreme Court struck down the Defense of Marriage Act and declared that the federal government couldn‚Äôt restrict the right to marriage based on gender. Another important step, but it was still an incomplete victory.

On this day in 2003, the Supreme Court reaffirmed one of the most important rights in America: the right to privacy, especially in our most intimate spaces. Lawrence v. Texas changed the lives of millions, but it was only a single step.
